Magazine Life & Leisure Search Home Companies Markets Street Talk Politics Policy World Property Technology Opinion Wealth Work & Careers Life & Luxury More Today's Paper Markets Data Events Lists Insights Advertisement Life & Luxury Arts & Culture Lunch with the AFR MONA founder David Walsh says the museum is 'my hotted-up Torana' As someone famously obsessed with sex and death, it makes senses the iconoclastic art patron sees his famous Hobart museum as a tool to help him 'bang above his weight'. David Walsh chose to have lunch with the AFR at Hobart pizza and pasta joint Da Angelo's rather his own restaurant Faro ‚Äì "it's too loud". R√©mi Chauvin Gabriella Coslovich Saleroom writer Nov 27, 2020 ‚Äì 9.26am Save Log in or Subscribe to save article Share Copy link Copied Email LinkedIn Twitter Facebook Copy link Copied Share via... Gift this article Subscribe to gift this article Gift 5 articles to anyone you choose each month when you subscribe. Subscribe now Already a subscriber? Login David Walsh didn't have a clue what the restaurant scene was like in Hobart when he was growing up in the working-class suburb of Glenorchy in the 1960s and '70s. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt go to a restaurant except for my 13th birthday,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI otherwise didn‚Äôt go to a restaurant until I was older than 18.‚Äù Loading... Find out more Read More Gabriella Coslovich Saleroom writer Gabriella Coslovich is an arts journalist with more than 20 years‚Äô experience, including 15 at The Age, where she was a senior arts writer. Her book, Whiteley on Trial, on Australia‚Äôs most audacious of alleged art fraud, won a Walkley in 2018. Contact | Mona Skip to main content ERROR: bookingSidebar is not in a valid state Tickets Visit Mona Visit Mona Accessibility Tickets FAQs Stuff to do View all Art Eat + drink Music Library Stay Really fancy stuff to do Other stuff The O Mona Blog Kirsha Kaechele Shop stuff View all Mona shop Moorilla Domaine A Moo Brew Gift cards Contact Contact Employment Subscribe Functions Search ‚Ä¢ Home Contact Contact MONA, MUSEUM OF OLD AND NEW ART 655 Main Road, Berriedale Hobart, Tasmania 7011 Australia Bookings and enquiries Any questions about your visit to Mona? Get in touch. visit@mona.net.au +61 (3) 6277 9978 Our Bookings and Enquiries office operates 9am‚Äì5pm, six days a week (closed Tuesdays). Refunds and exchanges Fill out the form below to request a refund or exchange on your booking with Mona. Our team will be in touch about your request within five working days. Thanks for understanding. Request a refund or exchange Lost Tickets Request a new link to your mobile tickets here. Mobile tickets Accommodation Enquire about staying in our super-flash, luxury dens on the river. accommodation@mona.net.au +61 (3) 6277 9911 Functions Want to do a function with us? We‚Äôve got lots of places for them. functions@mona.net.au Partnerships Keys in the bowl: let‚Äôs talk partnerships, sponsorship and business collaboration opportunities. partnerships@mona.net.au Media Our media team looks after all media enquiries about Mona and its associated subsidiaries. Please contact us for media releases, information, images, interviews, commercial filming enquiries or to arrange a visit. All filming and photography requests are subject to an approval process that involves a formal assessment by operational, curatorial, marketing, legal and commercial departments. Contact us for more info or to submit a request. media@mona.net.au Unsolicited proposals There is a remote chance that something you do now will be good. The chances of it being original, however, are pretty much zero. But do send us your proposal‚Äîsometimes we like hearing about your hopes and dreams, or that rap you‚Äôve written for David‚Äîif you think it‚Äôs actually worth reading. unsolicitedproposals@mona.net.au Please don‚Äôt contact the front desk asking if we‚Äôve read your proposal. We have. And if you send us stuff in the mail, we will not send it back. We get sent a lot of stuff. Hope you understand. Complaints about the goldfish If you‚Äôre vegetarian or vegan (and not just on Monday nights), and you want to make a complaint about the goldfish we have in a bowl in the museum, please email us. goldfishinabowl@mona.net.au If you eat meat or fish, maybe don‚Äôt email anyone. Music enquiries We put on live music most days we‚Äôre open. If you (and your free-jazz trip-hop octet) would like to throw your hat in the ring, sling us an email, but bear in mind we get a lot of free-jazz trip-hop octets reaching out, so you better be good. music@mona.net.au We‚Äôve also got a recording studio , if you‚Äôre after that sort of thing. Professional art services CAIR: Consultancy Artwork Installation & Realisation Our install team is waiting for you. We know all the tricks in the trade when it comes to museum-standard handling principles, including the installation of: Paintings, textiles, photography, and works on paper; Historical artefacts; Mixed media/ephemeral installation and sculptural artworks; Time-based media. We can also advise on a diverse range of museum-standard mount systems, and test existing building substrates for load-bearing suitability. ben@mona.net.au Purchase Orders Mona buys stuff. In order to do that, we issue purchase orders. The terms and conditions for our purchase orders are available here, if you‚Äôre looking / curious. Purchase order terms pdf Whistleblower Policy Mona has a whistleblower reporting policy which is available here . We have engaged an independent provider, Your Call, to receive reports via their website‚Äîavailable here . Kirsha Kaechele | Mona Skip to main content ERROR: bookingSidebar is not in a valid state Tickets Visit Mona Visit Mona Accessibility Tickets FAQs Stuff to do View all Art Eat + drink Music Library Stay Really fancy stuff to do Other stuff The O Mona Blog Kirsha Kaechele Shop stuff View all Mona shop Moorilla Domaine A Moo Brew Gift cards Contact Contact Employment Subscribe Functions Search ‚Ä¢ Other Stuff Kirsha Kaechele Kirsha Kaechele American artist, curator, and the other half of MONA ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt do it if it‚Äôs ugly. I‚Äôm completely uninterested in social work that is not simultaneously aesthetic, and simultaneously an interesting conceptual artwork.‚Äô Kirsha is the First Lady of Mona‚Äîthe boss‚Äôs missus, Mona‚Äôs better half, or Mrs. Mona if you prefer. The stiletto-toting Yank, and Tassie local since 2010, enhances our core activity with a series of projects that marry an almost vigilante approach to beauty with outrageous glamour, and specific social outcomes. Kirsha is a colourful counterpart to her august mate, who is less interested in beauty than in taking it apart and understanding how it works. She‚Äôs drawn to problems rather than avoiding them‚Äîand places transformation at the heart of her work, a lifelong quest to turn flaws into features, shit into gold. Kirsha¬†was interviewed by Elizabeth Pearce, Mona Research Curator and Senior Writer, in July 2016. EP : Why are you opening a hacking school? KK : It seemed like a good evolution of my CA$H 4 GUN$ project. At first I thought it would be fun to do as a conceptual artwork, but I wasn‚Äôt serious‚Äîit seemed a bit too Black Panthers. Although, now that I say that, I realise that Robert Trivers, the evolutionary biologist who is one of our hacking school‚Äôs spiritual guides, actually was a Black Panther. He got excommunicated ‚Äòfor his own good‚Äô. Anyway, a hacking school sounds dangerous and exciting, and is therefore attractive to at-risk youth. I mean, these guys are literally killing each other and selling crack, so it‚Äôs not like they are going to sign up for your feel good, let‚Äôs-all-love-one-another self-improvement program. Basically I want to overthrow traditional ideas of what social work looks like‚Äîugly. And what social programs feel like‚Äîdorky and boring. It‚Äôs tech education disguised as a hacking program‚Äîhoused in a secret, Dr-Strangelove-meets-James-Bond villain lair. EP : I am always trying to work out where the line is in your projects between art and social justice. KK : I can't do it if it's ugly. I'm completely uninterested in social work that is not simultaneously aesthetic, and simultaneously an interesting conceptual artwork. This is important because it impacts what I am able to give‚Ä¶ I mean, it‚Äôs not really my giving, it‚Äôs David‚Äôs giving. But the level to which I am prepared to manipulate him into doing what I want is directly tied to how aesthetically rewarding the project is. So if we're going to have a garden program‚Äîyeah, okay, I'll get behind a garden program. But I probably won't really start to drive it and expand it to new communities and put all that effort in unless I feel like it's an inspiring, radical reinvention of what a garden program looks like.¬†The basest part of me wants to be at a five-star hotel lapping up luxury treatments at the spa. I can redirect that drive to social work if it becomes art, and if it becomes an engine for societal reinvention... Read more Eat the Problem Eat the Problem What happens if we do something with our problems, rather than simply bemoan them? In this case, the problem lies with species that invade and degrade native ecologies. And the solution, perhaps, is to eat them. Watch Eat the Invaders on ABC iview Read More The Book Read more about the Eat the Problem here . Forest Economics Congress Forest Economics Congress An act of radical diplomacy uniting economists, the forestry industry, scientists, conservationists and artists at Mona, to tackle the question: what is the true value of Tasmania‚Äôs forests? Like the Congress itself, this question is evolving, and the project ongoing. Read more Material Institute Material Institute ‚ÄòAesthetics are a social justice issue‚Äô, declares Kirsha. Which is why, perhaps, she founded Material Institute‚Äîa non-profit social project and registered charity, reaching from Tassie to the USA, New Orleans to here in Hobart. The Institute seeks to fashion a better, more beautiful world of healthy, resilient communities, in which children can achieve their full potential. Read more Beauty Lab ‚Ä¢ Botanical ‚Ä¢ Botanical Kitchen & Cafe ‚Ä¢ Bond Place ‚Ä¢ Clay & Art Studio ‚Ä¢ Market Garden ‚Ä¢ 24 Carrot Gardens Ladies Lounge Ladies Lounge The lounge was a tremendously lavish space in our museum in which women could indulge in decadent nibbles, fancy tipples, and other ladylike pleasures‚Äîhosted and entertained by the fabulous butler. No boys allowed (the Supreme Court said so). The Ladies Lounge at Mona is now closed. Read more Read an interview with Kirsha on the Ladies Lounge here . 24 Carrot Gardens 24 Carrot Gardens A kitchen garden program in Tasmanian schools, where kids learn to grow, cook and eat healthy produce with a garden-to-plate ethos. Read more Ca$h 4 Gun$ Ca$h 4 Gun$ A conceptual artwork in the form of a gun buyback scheme in New Orleans. Read an interview with Kirsha here . Read more Ancient History Ancient History The School A conceptual artwork in the form of a school. Programs include: Hacking School Students learn to break the internet, bit by bit, in collaboration with Ivy League legends. Think world domination by way of code, makers‚Äô workshops, active hacking and learning, theory, ethics / how to avoid jail, and systems thinking. The Makeup of the Universe Students learn about the stars‚ÄîMiss Universe and the universe‚Äîwhile earning a degree in beauty. Guest lecturers include Nobel Prize‚Äìwinner Brian P. Schmidt who discovered that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate. He‚Äôs the recipient of our inaugural makeover. Jung-le Gym Where conceptual art meets exercise: students act out inner darkness and human archetypes in muscle building aerobic-style, inspired by Carl Jung. Classes take place in open, outdoor spaces, as well as a gymnasium filled with equipment designed by artists and engineers. The Embassy Students lay tracks, produce records, write lyrics, and participate in delivery and recording workshops led by esteemed producers. Bio Lab Where art meets biological building and research. Students learn the ethics of bioengineering (controversial terrain), create non-toxic nail polishes, designer genes (and jeans), and everything in between‚Äîincluding ways in which we could turn the entire building into a living organism. We‚Äôre of the opinion that technology is becoming biology: ‚Äòit‚Äô becomes ‚Äòthem‚Äô, and then it becomes ‚Äòus‚Äô. So, what will it be? Or should that be ‚Äòus‚Äô? KKProjects New Orleans A project based in the St. Roch neighborhood of New Orleans in six previously abandoned structures: a former bakery, a storefront, and four 1800s houses. Each housed a site-specific installation for a three month exhibition period, with local and international artists invited to work with the spaces as they found them, as well as with the surrounding physical and cultural environment. KK vs BS (Big Salmon) Ridiculous and puerile at best, inciting violence at worst. ‚ÄîHuon Aquaculture boss Frances Bender Watch here Mona Victory Gardens A project turning Mona‚Äôs ‚Äòfucking useless‚Äô lawns‚Äîthe erstwhile site of markets and concerts, beanbags and wine‚Äîinto a bountiful vegetable garden during COVID-19, complete with social media competition encouraging the general public to follow along at home while cultivating their own victory garden. View the weekly video series here . The River Derwent Heavy Metal Project Heavy Metal brings together art and science to address the pollution problem from multiple, creative angles. Press MoMa (Mona Market) An al fresco extravaganza of music and food, art and performance, science and craft (of the non-naff variety). A glamorous, roaming collision of high and low art, held on Sundays in the summertime. MoMa‚Äîonly slightly shitter than Salamanca market. Much, much shitter than the MoMA in New York. Stalkk @kirshakaechele Interview with Kirsha Kaechele about the Ladies Lounge 7 May 2024 In a recent ruling by the Tasmanian Civil and Administrative Tribunal, artist and curator Kirsha Kaechele was ordered to allow men entry to the Ladies Lounge, her artwork at Mona. On a recent flight to Milan, Kaechele sat down to discuss the court‚Äôs decision and the future of the artwork. Forest Economics Congress: New A$$. class 17 August 2023 A few years ago, I was invited to do the keynote for the Tasmanian Economic Forum. You‚Äôve got the wrong person, I told them. Of all subjects on earth, economics is the one I know least about. And definitely care least about. One need only begin to say the word, econo ‚Ä¶ zzzzzzz ‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôm snoozing off. But they insisted: they wanted someone from outside their world, someone fresh, to shake things up. Fine. But I should at least offer something relevant to their forum. So I did some calculations and presented this graph: Talkk Male visitor sues Mona over women-only Ladies Lounge Gabriella Coslovich ‚Ä¢ Sydney Morning Herald Hobart‚Äôs popular Museum of Old and New Art (Mona) could be forced to shut down its women-only Ladies Lounge created by Kirsha Kaechele, wife of museum founder David Walsh, if an anti-discrimination case launched by a male visitor is successful... How Kirsha Kaechele brought the logging industry‚Äôs most powerful players together Nick O'Malley ‚Ä¢ Sydney Morning Herald Everyone is curious about Mona founder David Walsh and his American wife Kirsha Kaechele, an artist and curator. As word got out that she was planning conference about the logging industry, people were immediately intrigued... I don‚Äôt actually give a fuck about diamonds, I prefer my husband pay for my social projects. üñ§ Saved Subscribe to the MONA Mailing List Email address By subscribing, you accept the terms and conditions listed in Mona's privacy policy Facebook Threads Instagram YouTube ¬© Museum of Old and New Art 2025 .
